page.title: 13Ecology of NW Derby
page.content: Approximately 60% of the area is an urban environment with the sorts of habitat common to city areas: hedge- rows & semi-cultivated areas such as grass verges & school playing fields, scattered trees usually planted singly or in small groups for landscaping, wasteground, refuse tips the buildings themselves & the parks. Markeaton Lake & the River Derwent provide the major aquatic habitats & nesting sites for waterfowl. The remaining 40% of the area is farmland of many years stand- ing, consequently there are no large woodland areas and no apparent ancient woodland areas of any account. Hedge- rows are predominantly hawthorn with also elder, hazel and holly. The most common trees are ash, sycamore, oak & beech. Lichen growth on tree trunks would suggest a relatively high back- ground level of air pollution.
